baseline_groups.claim_summary: Employment-to-employment (EE) reallocation rate is a strong positive predictor of nominal earnings growth at the market-time level, dominating the explanatory power of unemployment-to-employment (UE) transitions.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coef on xee = 0.309 (SE 0.007, p<0.001). With UE control: coef on xee = 0.242 (SE 0.011, p<0.001). With UE+UR controls: coef on xee = 0.224 (SE 0.016, p<0.001). EE dominates even when controlling for UE and UR transitions.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: UE transition rate also predicts wage growth but with smaller magnitude than EE.
baseline_groups.notes: UE bivariate coef = 0.024 (SE 0.0006, p<0.001). When controlling for EE: coef on xue drops to 0.0076.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Unemployment rate predicts wage growth but EE explains most of the variation.

global_notes: Paper studies the relative predictive power of EE vs UE transitions for wage growth using SIPP data aggregated to demographic market x month level. Results are extremely robust -- 98.4% of specifications are positive and significant. The baseline_ee_ue_ue spec reports the UE coefficient from the horse race model (G2). The spec baseline_ee_ue reports the EE coefficient from the same horse race.
